theme.title: The staff
theme.para: In the Western musical notation system music is written on specially printed paper called 'manuscript paper' (see next picture):

The manuscript paper is organized as sets of horizontal lines, named 'staves', and each group of horizontal lines is called a 'staff' (in British English the word 'staff' is old-fashioned and rarely used; the word 'stave' is used instead). A staff is a set of five horizontal lines, numbered from bottom to top; the bottom line is the first line and the top line is the fifth line:

score.music: (score (vers 1.5)(language en iso-8859-1) (opt Staff.DrawLeftBarline no) (instrument (musicData (clef G noVisible)(key C)(time 2 4 noVisible) (spacer 500) (graphic line 5 0 80 -20) (graphic line 5 10 80 0) (graphic line 5 20 80 20) (graphic line 5 30 80 40) (graphic line 5 40 80 60) (text ''line 5'' dx:90 dy:-10 left (font normal 10)) (text ''line 4'' dx:90 dy:10 left (font normal 10)) (text ''line 3'' dx:90 dy:30 left (font normal 10)) (text ''line 2'' dx:90 dy:50 left (font normal 10)) (text ''line 1'' dx:90 dy:70 left (font normal 10)) (barline end noVisible) ) ) )

theme.para: The four spaces between the staff lines, are important and are also numbered from bottom to top:

score.music: (score (vers 1.5)(language en iso-8859-1) (opt Staff.DrawLeftBarline no) (instrument (musicData (clef G noVisible)(key C)(time 2 4 noVisible) (spacer 500) (graphic line 5 5 80 -10) (graphic line 5 15 80 10) (graphic line 5 25 80 30) (graphic line 5 35 80 50) (text ''space 4'' dx:90 dy:0 left (font normal 10)) (text ''space 3'' dx:90 dy:20 left (font normal 10)) (text ''space 2'' dx:90 dy:40 left (font normal 10)) (text ''space 1'' dx:90 dy:60 left (font normal 10)) (barline end noVisible) ) ) )

theme.para: The musical symbols are placed on the staff and the music on the staff is read from left to right.

The symbols for notes are placed either on a line or on a space and the musical pitch (sound) is determined by the position of the note on the staff. Notes on the higher lines/spaces have higher pitch than those on the lower ones:

score.music: (score (vers 1.5)(language en iso-8859-1) (opt Staff.DrawLeftBarline no) (instrument (musicData (clef G noVisible)(key C)(time 2 4 noVisible) (text ''First note has higher pitch than second one'' dx:0 dy:80) (spacer 100) (n c5 w) (n e4 w) (barline end noVisible) ) ) )

theme.para: As an example, press the 'Play' link and listen to the next score:

score.music: (score (vers 1.5)(language en iso-8859-1) (opt Staff.DrawLeftBarline no) (opt Render.SpacingMethod fixed) (opt Render.SpacingValue 15) (instrument (musicData (clef G noVisible)(key C)(time 2 4 noVisible) (text ''Pitch increases as the note is higher'' dx:0 dy:80) (spacer 50) (n e4 w)(spacer 20) (n f4 w)(spacer 20) (n g4 w)(spacer 20) (n a4 w)(spacer 20) (n b4 w)(spacer 20) (n c5 w)(spacer 20) (n d5 w)(spacer 20) (n e5 w)(spacer 20) (n f5 w)(spacer 50) (barline end noVisible) ) ) )
